values:
Now what my opinion on weither the McCanns may or may not have been responsible for the death of their child is beside the point HOWEVER what I DO think is...

I have myself asked questions concerning their conduct, the evidence they present and the way they 'spin' news stories and try to presure the police into droping the case and seeking to involve the Goverment in this.

Other people i know have done the same and even went further.

All these opinions, all these arguments are removed from the Web or never allowed to make it on sites in the first place.

The Press tell us the GreatBritishPublic love the McCanns and think they have done nothing wrong even if this is only in deserting their children to go out and get sloshed.

The press tell us this but I know no one who is completly uncritical of the McCanns and, indeed, most f the people i know think they are guilty of something between bad parenting and manslaughter. What's the problem then? Why do none of these negitive comments make it online? Why dothe press mis-represent the views they know are prevelent in the country?

Well the McCanns are Doctors arn't they? They're goodmiddleclasschristians arn't they?

Well I for one am sick of this.

The press are manipulating you and everyone you know. They don't report the true opinion of the country, they don't report all the evidence that comes out, they report the hlf-truths of the McCanns (that the investigation is going nowhere, that the police allowed them to return to Britain - they did a midnight flit - and so on and so on.) 

Don't beleve a thing you read.

One great example of this is that the Goverment paid for a PR Agent to help them during the first month of the investigation.

I've got a job!

It's a sh*t one but three month's of employment is good isn't it?

AND I finaly got my laptop back after five onths in police custody!

I was thinknig lately about the existance of evil places, that is arias which bring out the worst in people, encorage in humanity and violance.

In the review of a book on murders in 1920s and 30's Chicago in FT it was remarked that Chicago at that time seemed to bring out any evil potential a person had.

Well...

This week we had a woman Gang raped in Yorkhill, the body of a man subjected to a brutil atack found in the river Clide, a murder in a flat...not so much in a week as in two days.

Is Glasgow an Evil Place? Are the ghosts of it's past (the Slave trade in particuler) coming back to haunt us? Has a history of deprovation and violance left something in the air, in the soil?

so i've not updated for quite some time (well a week.)

In that time i've...

1. Been slightly run down
2. Unable to sleep well.
3. Reserching a EP I found of what may well be (or may not be) a 1970's Drag Act from Glasgow.

After non-stop drinking from Thursdsay onwards everyone's wound up and hyper agressive.

I've been threatend four times this long weekend, nearly knocked down three times, we've found two used needles near where we live, there's been cars smashed up and house windows panned in all along the street, someone tried to break into our block by repedidly hurling themselfs against the door while yelling at the top of their voice, the pub (that i've mentioned in other posts) has started a running 'Trannie' joke and so on, and so on.


And you wonder why I'm planing on getting out of glasgow?

Beating death symbolic of local tensions

By Crystal Carreon - Bee Staff Writer

Published 12:00 am PDT Friday, July 13, 2007
Story appeared in MAIN NEWS section, Page A1

Today, those who knew Satender Singh will gather at a Sacramento mortuary to mourn a young man whose life ended too soon, in a flash of violence his friends say was fueled by bigotry and fear.

They will come together to remember the 26-year-old, a Fijian immigrant, as meticulously dressed, always sharing a smile and a loud, melodic laugh that infused a room with joy.

Many who didn't know Singh will be there as well. In death, he has emerged as a symbol of wounds that have festered for some time between Sacramento's gay community and members of the Slavic evangelical community, a thousands-strong group that has become a vocal force denouncing gay rights. It is that rhetoric, some contend, that fueled the attack on Singh earlier this month at Lake Natoma.

"This homicide sort of brings to light what has been feared," said Sen. Darrell Steinberg, D-Sacramento, who attended a vigil for Singh last week. "It's tragic evidence of a larger point."

The circumstances surrounding the July 1 beating remain under investigation, but Sacramento County Sheriff John McGinness said this week "there is a strong probability" the assault was a hate crime. He characterized the case as high priority, and said detectives still want to speak with those involved and find the person responsible. As of Thursday, no arrests had been made.

Singh was picnicking near Lake Natoma with a small group of Fijian and Indian friends when the attack occurred, according to two people with him that day. The Bee is not identifying the friends because they fear retribution.

Singh was at the park that Sunday to celebrate a promotion he had earned at his call center job, according to the friends, and the group was drinking and dancing to Indian music. Singh was the only one without a date, and was hugging and dancing with other men.

In the hours preceding the attack, a group described as Russian-speaking hurled explicit gay slurs and racial remarks at Singh and his party, according to witnesses and sheriff's officials. When Singh and his friends tried to leave around 8 p.m., they were confronted by the Slavic group and a fight ensued, the witnesses said.

Singh was punched -- once -- in the face. He fell backward and cracked his head, rupturing a part of the brain stem that controls most of life's functions. He died four days later.

Singh's death has struck a deep chord in Sacramento's gay community, whose members have expressed concern in the past year over aggressive anti-gay protests Slavic evangelical Christians have staged at area schools and the Capitol.

"We could read the writing on the wall," said Nathan Feldman of Sacramento's "Being Gay Today" cable-access show. "This was not a random thing; this has been building up."

For the past year, Feldman said, he has documented the growing volatility around the protests, and was moved to stage a counter-protest last July at Bethany Slavic Missionary Church, the region's largest evangelical congregation.

The Sacramento area is home to about 100,000 Russian-speaking residents, community leaders say. About a third of those residents are evangelical Christians who espouse a literal interpretation of the Bible. Those leading the anti-gay protests -- many of whom fled religious persecution in the former Soviet Union -- maintain they're exercising their newfound freedom of speech to spread the message that homosexuality is a sin.

"What's going on is very complicated," Feldman said this week. "It's almost a social war starting in Sacramento."

Steinberg, who last year rode as a dignitary in the city's annual gay pride parade, said he has been struck by the magnitude of vitriol emanating from the evangelical protests.

"Some of the epithets, some of the signs are not only disrespectful of the gay and lesbian community, but they are disrespectful of the entire community," he said. "The words are vile ... and words may give people the implicit license to take the next step and hurt people."

Though sheriff's investigators have yet to identify Singh's attackers, leaders in the area's gay and Asian Pacific Islander communities have united behind the belief he was a victim of a hate crime and are responding in force.

Last week, the groups held vigils in his honor, and this week local leaders formed the Satender Justice Coalition, a task force that plans to host forums and letter-writing campaigns to call attention to acts of prejudice and bigotry.

"Why has Mr. Singh's death galvanized this community?" asked Georgette Imura of the Council of Asian Pacific Islanders Together for Advocacy. "He was targeted because of his ethnicity and his perceived sexual orientation ... and possibly, his racial background. It's touched us on so many different levels."

Florin Ciuriuc, a former executive director of the Slavic Community Center of Sacramento, said he was disturbed but not surprised to hear of the attack at Lake Natoma.

Ciuriuc said he was among those leading anti-gay protests a few years back but that he stopped participating as the movement became more menacing.

"I saw that people were hungry for violence, for blood; different ideas where we have to be aggressive, where we have to scream," he said. "I don't want people from my community killing each other or other people because they are getting aggressive."

Viktor Chernyetsky, administrator of Bethany Slavic Missionary Church, strongly disagreed with Ciuriuc's assessment. Chernyetsky said Slavic leaders teach homosexuality is a sin, but do not support physical violence.

"You can express your view legally. You can go to the Capitol. You can put up signs," Chernyetsky said. "But to resort to physical violence, we are strongly against this."

He said the community will continue to fight against gay rights because that is their moral duty.

"We see danger that comes from the gay community, in Sacramento especially," said Chernyetsky. "This issue is so important for our families and for our kids, and by the way, for the future for our country.

"So probably," he said, "we need to be more vocal."

Shirley Collins: Richie Story. From The Power of the True Love Knot album. A lovely evocation of hope and romance even if it's central motif (a King gives up his Kingdom to become the servent of a Lady he loves) is highly unlightly.

 

Wolf Eyes: Black Wing Over The Sand. Nice bit of noise to scare the neighbours. And a nice bit of packaging: the images of torture and dehumanisation might not be to everyone's taste but they provide (perhaps?) an explanatory not for the music not to mention an aresting cover design.

 

Goblin: Susperia. You know i HATE Argento - I find him deaply Mysoginistic to the point that he subjected his own Daughter to his Sexualised Troture fantasies in his 80's movies but this title track from Goblin's soundtrack to his 'classic' (read Mysoginistic and plain silly not to mention incredably borring) film is starteling and deaply unseteling. Claustraphobic 70's electronica mixes with horse whisper'd vocals producing an effect akin to an unsespected psychotic break sprinkled librarly with paranioa and auditory halusinations. Not for the feignt hearted. File with: Profundo Rosso (Goblin), Dawn of the Dead (Goblin and Argento) Il Gatto Nova Code (Morricone) and 4 Mosche Di Velluto Grigio (Morricone.)

 

COB: Evening Air. And now we open the windows and let the light in. Well kind of...A delecate evocation of loss pitching the mourner after lost love into the fire of Visionary experence.

 

Efterklang: Towards The Bare Hill. Strange post-rock with a whispering Chorus.

 

Monosov Swirnoff: Sail on. 11 odd minutes of various instraments grinding slowely. More Modern Classical than Rock and Roll.

 

Rey Roig Y Su Sencation: Son Sabroson. New York / Cuban fussion from the late 70's. Some call it Boogaloo but that's just an invented term. Get up off your seat and start doing the dishes (well OK: dance then.)

 

Nico: Chelsea Girls.

 

Dead Kenedies: Saturday Nights Holocaust. The Final Solution re-enacted in Middle America: chilling and hilarious.

 

Jun Tabor: Joe Peel. Makes me cry every time I hear it...

Albums

Son Cubano NYC: Cuban Roots, ney York Spices 1972 - 1982

 

Goblin: Susperia

 

Shirley Collins: The Power Of The True Love Knot.

 

Bert Jansch: Rosmerry Lane. Not his best album but it has it's moments.

 

Monosov Swirnoff/ The Shining Path: Recorded Works 2.

 

COB: Spirit of Love.

 

Nico: Chelsea Girl. Again not the artist's best work but it has it's moments

 

The Vitimin B12: A Date at the Rendozvous. Lound Jazz gives way to epic free form madness when a house Jazz band lets rip. Witty and delightfull.

 

Our Own Voices (a Trikont sampler.)

 

Tim Hart and Maddie Prior: Folk Songs of Olde England Vol. 1.

Lesbian Killing In South Africa: We Demand Justice!

(July 9, 2007) The South African lesbian and gay communities through the Joint Working Group* and partner organisations STRONGLY CONDEMN the killing of Sizakele Sigasa (34) and Salome Masooa (23) from a township in Johannesburg. They were found (Sunday 8th July) murdered, execution style, in a nearby field in Meadowlands; a shocking image that is not so new in South Africa in the light of the recent increase in violence and rape against women either identified as, suspected of or supporting lesbian and gay rights.

Gays and lesbians are men and women, human beings who deserve equal rights and treatment - not to be ridiculed or called names, beaten, tortured, raped or killed. These gross human rights violations are not just inhuman and barbaric - they must not be tolerated! Sizakele and Salome's killers, like everyone else, HAD NO RIGHT TO THREATEN OR KILL THEM!!

Violence against lesbians and gays is unSouth African. Here, oppression and discrimination have no place, still there are parents who reject or kick children out to the streets; siblings, friends and communities who hurt, beat, rape, torture and even kill lesbians and gays. If they survive all this, they face further victimisation at in the hands of the police and even the courts - THIS IS NOT JUSTICE AT ALL. People who inflict harm upon and even kill lesbians and gays (or anyone else) do not belong in South Africa. Leaders and communities that do not oppose violence against gays, lesbians, women, children, rape survivors and HIV+ people do not belong here.

1) We call on the Meadowlands Police Services to investigate this matter - efficiently and rigorously;

2) We call on other state bodies and communities to support the families by working with the Police and the Prosecuting Authorities towards ensuring that the killers are brought to book.

We express our deepest condolences to the bereaved families and friends. We offer our support to the colleagues and comrades as they mourn the death of these two precious women.

MEMORIAL SERVICE: Thursday 12 July 2007, 12h00-15h00 (Epelegeng Centre)

FUNERAL: Saturday, 14 July 2007, 12h00 (Meadowlands Community Centre)

I Will Survive singer wants to 'lead gays to Christ'
Facebook   StumbleUpon   Seed Newsvine Digg   Del.icio.us   Furl


13th July 2007 12:01
PinkNews.co.uk writer

Gloria Gaynor, the American singer whose hit I Will Survive is seen as a gay anthem, told Radio 4 this morning that gay people should embrace Christ and that her status as a gay icon allows her to lead them to Him.

She repeatedly refused to say whether or not she thinks homosexuality is wrong.

Many readers have contacted PinkNews.co.uk to complain about her comments.

Ms Gaynor, a committed Christian, is currently on a tour of the UK.

When asked by presenter Jane Little how she feels about being a gay icon, she replied:

"I feel good about it because I feel it is a platform for my purpose, which is to bring the love of Christ to all of my fans.

"Because they trust me, I think."

Ms Little asked: "So you see it as an evangelistic thing. Do you have a religious opposition to homosexuality?"

GG: "I want to lead them to Christ and what he has for them. I want to lead them to him, I want to lead them to truth."

JL: "Do you see homosexuality as something sinful?"

GG: "I want to lead them to Christ, simply, and whatever he has for them."

PinkNews.co.uk reader Anne Morgan said:

"I think this is incredible considering her songs are both gay and feminist anthems. In the same interview she replied "Oh no" when asked if she was a feminist.

"I wonder what would happen her record sales in the UK if it was widely known how homophobic she is."

Listen to the interview with Gloria Gaynor here

http://www.pinknews.co.uk/news/articles/2005-4931.html

remember the couple in Packistan who wher eimprisoned because the Husband hadn't been born with a d*ck? They've been relesed:

Bail for Pakistan 'same-sex' pair
Doctors say Raj is still a woman, despite sex change operations
Pakistan's Supreme Court has ordered that a couple jailed for perjury in a row over the husband's sex should be released on bail, their lawyers say.

The ruling came after a judge agreed to hear appeals against the convictions.

The couple say they are man and wife, but the Lahore high court ruled last month that the husband was, in fact, a woman, despite sex-change surgery.

The case is thought the first of its kind in Pakistan where homosexuality and trans-sexuality are largely taboo.

'Lied'

Shumail Raj, 31, had sex-change surgery to become a man and then married Shahzina Tariq, 24, a cousin.

The judgement of the high court has been suspended and the Supreme Court has ordered their release
Lawyer Babar Awan

She was aware of his condition but says she needed his help to avoid being forced into wedlock with someone else.

The couple originally sought the protection of the courts but were arrested last month after the bride's family questioned whether Raj was a man.

Judges in Lahore jailed the couple for three years and fined them 10,000 Pakistani rupees ($165).

They found that the couple had lied about Raj's sexual status and said their marriage was un-Islamic because it was same-sex.

But on Thursday, the couple's lawyers said the judgement of the high court had been suspended

"The Supreme Court has ordered their release," said lawyer Babar Awan, Reuters news agency reports.

Bail is reported to have been set at 50,000 rupees ($825) each.

No date has been given for the appeal hearing to begin.

'Against Islam'

Raj is reported to have undergone surgery twice in Pakistan over the past 16 years to become a man.

Shumail Raj (left) and Shahzina Tariq appealed to the president

But tests carried out by doctors on behalf of the Lahore high court ruled that Raj, who has a beard and moustache, was still a woman.

Raj himself says that he needs to go abroad for more treatment even though his breasts and uterus have been removed.

Ms Tariq's family wants to annul the wedding on the grounds that it is against Islam for two women to marry.

But the couple argue that they married to protect the bride from being sold into marriage to pay off her uncle's gambling debts.

Ms Tariq says they are not homosexuals and they married because they are in love.

This man thinks Queers are 'repulsive'



Paisley refuses to apologise for gay remarks
Facebook   StumbleUpon   Seed Newsvine Digg   Del.icio.us   Furl



22nd June 2007 15:00
Tony Grew

A junior minister in the government of Northern Ireland has stood by his comments that gay people are repulsive.

Ian Paisley Jnr rejected calls for him to apologise. He is a junior minister in the Northern Ireland Executive, headed by his father Rev Ian Paisley.

"What is done is done, I've said those comments why should I try and hide what I've done," Mr Paisley told the local politics programme Let's Talk last night.

He pointed out that his statements were not against the law. Sinn Fein and SDLP members of the local Assembly have demanded an apology.

Mr Paisley, 41, told Hotpress magazine last month:

"I am pretty repulsed by gay and lesbianism. I think it is wrong. I think that those people harm themselves and - without caring about it - harm society.

"That doesn't mean to say that I hate them. I mean, I hate what they do."

There has been concern at Mr Paisley's remarks because the Office of First Minister and Deputy First Minister, where he is a junior minister, is responsible for ensuring equality for gay people.

Mr Paisley Jnr is a member of the DUP representing Antrim North in the Northern Ireland Assembly.

He was appointed to the government job by his father, First Minister Ian Paisley Snr, in May.

Northern Ireland gay rights activist Andrew Muir pointed out that Mr Paisley's comments could cause harm, despite his protestations that he does not hate gay people.

"Our research proves that 29% of young people have actually attempted suicide because of homophobia in society and I think these comments are very concerning."

Rise in domestic abuse among gay couples reported


Facebook   StumbleUpon   Seed Newsvine Digg   Del.icio.us   Furl 


20th June 2007 15:55
Tony Grew

Leading doctors in the UK have warned of an epidemic of domestic abuse across the country.

29% of gay men and 22% of lesbians have been victims. A report from the BMA revealed that a third of women first suffered abuse at home while pregnant.

The study found that three-quarters of a million children are repeatedly exposed to domestic abuse, but doctors claim that the figures are underestimated because of a lack of reporting.

Dr Vivienne Nathanson, head of science and ethics at the BMA, said: "The figures we provide are shocking, but perhaps more alarming is that they are likely to be grossly underestimated.

"Domestic abuse is an unspoken scar on our society and many individuals never report that they are victims."

The BMA is calling for better training to help doctors spot abuse and more funding for refuge centres.

Professor Gene Feder, who contributed to the report, said: "If domestic abuse was an illness, we would call it an epidemic. It is having a real effect on public health."

you'll only be detained under new legislation.

In 2005 the Goverment tried to bring in a law allowing one psych to have you locked up but the BMA, Psychs, Nurses and Mental Health Campaigners didn't want it   -and neither did parlament. 

Well under ammendments to the Mental Health Act 2007 and the Mental Capacity Act 2007 they have done it. You can now be detailed almost indefinatly on the word of one psych.

The new legislation is as bad as the old as it includes Depression and Homosexuality as reasons for doing it. 

Particularly protection of Queers has been removed ( see here:  http://www.officeronline.co.uk/news/273419.aspx ) but this leaves the way open this to happen.

In adition the Goverment has cloosed the loophole in compulsery detention offerd by the Bournewood Rulling in the European Court of Human Rights. This arose when an individual volentrly booked themselfs into a mental health unit and when they tried to leave where prevented and told they would be in hospital for 'a long time.' 

You can, as far as I can tell, appeal a dessision but the case can take up to a year to reach court. Or, to put it another way, you could be locked up for a year in a mental health setting for no reason other than you met with an unfriendly Psych that dosn't like Queers or you went to the Doctor to get Anti-Depressents.

Welcome to the new Britain and now let us break for the Four Minute Hate.

Weird, dark, lo-fi folk/ blues/ country strangness from Wooden Wand (think Davandra Barnhard - sp! - gone over to the dark side) to be had here: http://www.woodenwand.net/

Lots and lots of noise art nonsence (in frence) to be had here: http://galerie.pache.free.fr/pagemp3.html#allunmp3

Half Man Half Buscit sessions here: http://www.hmhb.co.uk/

Punk Pop from Dammaged Goods: http://www.damagedgoods.co.uk/sounds/index.html

That should do you lot. ;)

We've desided to go to the Comunity Police now. i can't stand it much longer.

1. Stuckometer: Jordell Bank (in the palm of your hand) parts 1 + 2. More weird noise :) Look here: http://galerie.pache.free.fr/Page2.html and you'll get a free download if you go down the page. WARNING! The page is in french!
  2. COB: Scranky Black Farmer. Odd haunting and haunted arangment of a traditional song. Think allianation and disasosiation and you'l lbe getting close.
  3. Bonnie Chaplan: Polander Hevy Epic. Take Polish Disco, play it at the wrong speed...
  4. Shirlley Collins: I drew my ship.
  5. Captain Beefheart and the Magic Band: Troup Mask Replica. Hard to listen to? Yes but not as hard as it's made out to be. Worth the effort.
  6. Bruno nicoli: Une Journee Bien Remplie. From (one of) the other Italian soundtrack composers of the 60s and 70s. And yes he did colabarate with Ennio morricone.
  7. Mr. Fox: Salsbery Plain. Old favorates return.
  8. The mystery Water Saloon Boys: The Smuggler. 10 odd minutes of muffled vocals and weird instramentation from some oddballs from Leeds. I quote: 'the Mystery Water Saloon Boys is Phil Todd's vehicle for group workouts in atmospheric and psychedelic jams. This disc features the duo of Phil Todd (Ashtray Navigations) and Chris Hladowski (Scatter, Nalle) exploring everywhere from twisted deep space raga to edgy paranoid ramblings using strings, effects, voice, reeds, wind, and percussion all mixed and mangled onto a very damaged old tape deck.' http://www.skullsofheaven.com/index.php?alpha=m
  9. Orphin Fairytale: Seahorse Soup. Again i quote: 'Femme-punk psych using toy instruments, cheap drum clank, keyboards, vocals and magic dust that sounds something like Suckdog-plays-Sun Ra in an isolated European bedsit.' http://www.volcanictongue.co.uk/artist.php?art=Orphan+Fairytale
  10. John Zorn: The Big Gundown (album.) john zorn (avant' composer) reforms Morricone and produces a work of genius. http://www.omnology.com/zorn01.html

Now this isn't a critisism of the SNP (take note
endless_psych ) but a more general set of thoughts.

Nationalism, 'the last refuge of the scoundrel' as (I beleve Dr. Johnson said) and the seed-bed of puritinism. My worries are what the rise of nationalism will meen for Scotland's immagrent workforce and, on a personal leval, what it wil meen for Queers.

These are more conected than you think: the rise of Nationalist fealing could well result in the rise of a puritanical drive towards asking what 'pure' Scitishness is. What then? Well the Polish workers won't be Scotish enough (and given how menny building sites I've saw around they're driving Glasgow's regeneration) and neither will the Queers.

We'll see Scotland becoming a frightening place soon if my worst fears come true. I personaly am making plans to get out in a year or two. I was here during the 'Keep the Clause' campaign ( http://www.scottishmediamonitor.com/features2.cfm?ID=18 - for the youngsters amongst you) and i know how deep homaphobia runs in the Scotish blood and how vicious it is and I don't want to be here if it happens again.
